verses.text: Yes, fields will once again be bought and sold—deeds signed and sealed and witnessed—in the land of Benjamin and here in Jerusalem, in the towns of Judah and in the hill country, in the foothills of Judah and in the Negev, too. For someday I will restore prosperity to them. I, the Lord, have spoken!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While Jeremiah was still confined in the courtyard of the guard, the Lord gave him this second message:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what the Lord says—the Lord who made the earth, who formed and established it, whose name is the Lord:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ask me and I will tell you remarkable secrets you do not know about things to come.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For this is what the Lord, the God of Israel, says: You have torn down the houses of this city and even the king’s palace to get materials to strengthen the walls against the siege ramps and swords of the enemy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You expect to fight the Babylonians, but the men of this city are already as good as dead, for I have determined to destroy them in my terrible anger. I have abandoned them because of all their wickedness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Nevertheless, the time will come when I will heal Jerusalem’s wounds and give it prosperity and true peace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will restore the fortunes of Judah and Israel and rebuild their towns.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will cleanse them of their sins against me and forgive all their sins of rebellion.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then this city will bring me joy, glory, and honor before all the nations of the earth! The people of the world will see all the good I do for my people, and they will tremble with awe at the peace and prosperity I provide for them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what the Lord says: You have said, ‘This is a desolate land where people and animals have all disappeared.’ Yet in the empty streets of Jerusalem and Judah’s other towns, there will be heard once more
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
the sounds of joy and laughter. The joyful voices of bridegrooms and brides will be heard again, along with the joyous songs of people bringing thanksgiving offerings to the Lord. They will sing,
‘Give thanks to the Lord of Heaven’s Armies,
    for the Lord is good.
    His faithful love endures forever!’
For I will restore the prosperity of this land to what it was in the past, says the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what the Lord of Heaven’s Armies says: This land—though it is now desolate and has no people and animals—will once more have pastures where shepherds can lead their flocks.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Once again shepherds will count their flocks in the towns of the hill country, the foothills of Judah, the Negev, the land of Benjamin, the vicinity of Jerusalem, and all the towns of Judah. I, the Lord, have spoken!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “The day will come, says the Lord, when I will do for Israel and Judah all the good things I have promised them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“In those days and at that time
    I will raise up a righteous descendant from King David’s line.
    He will do what is just and right throughout the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
In that day Judah will be saved,
    and Jerusalem will live in safety.
And this will be its name:
    ‘The Lord Is Our Righteousness.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For this is what the Lord says: David will have a descendant sitting on the throne of Israel forever.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And there will always be Levitical priests to offer burnt offerings and grain offerings and sacrifices to me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then this message came to Jeremiah from the Lord:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what the Lord says: If you can break my covenant with the day and the night so that one does not follow the other,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: only then will my covenant with my servant David be broken. Only then will he no longer have a descendant to reign on his throne. The same is true for my covenant with the Levitical priests who minister before me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And as the stars of the sky cannot be counted and the sand on the seashore cannot be measured, so I will multiply the descendants of my servant David and the Levites who minister before me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord gave another message to Jeremiah. He said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Have you noticed what people are saying?—‘The Lord chose Judah and Israel and then abandoned them!’ They are sneering and saying that Israel is not worthy to be counted as a nation.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But this is what the Lord says: I would no more reject my people than I would change my laws that govern night and day, earth and sky.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will never abandon the descendants of Jacob or David, my servant, or change the plan that David’s descendants will rule the descendants of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. Instead, I will restore them to their land and have mercy on them.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon came with all the armies from the kingdoms he ruled, and he fought against Jerusalem and the towns of Judah. At that time this message came to Jeremiah from the Lord:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Go to King Zedekiah of Judah, and tell him, ‘This is what the Lord, the God of Israel, says: I am about to hand this city over to the king of Babylon, and he will burn it down.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You will not escape his grasp but will be captured and taken to meet the king of Babylon face to face. Then you will be exiled to Babylon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “‘But listen to this promise from the Lord, O Zedekiah, king of Judah. This is what the Lord says: You will not be killed in war
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but will die peacefully. People will burn incense in your memory, just as they did for your ancestors, the kings who preceded you. They will mourn for you, crying, “Alas, our master is dead!” This I have decreed, says the Lord.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jeremiah the prophet delivered the message to King Zedekiah of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At this time the Babylonian army was besieging Jerusalem, Lachish, and Azekah—the only fortified cities of Judah not yet captured.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This message came to Jeremiah from the Lord after King Zedekiah made a covenant with the people, proclaiming freedom for the slaves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He had ordered all the people to free their Hebrew slaves—both men and women. No one was to keep a fellow Judean in bondage.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The officials and all the people had obeyed the king’s command,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but later they changed their minds. They took back the men and women they had freed, forcing them to be slaves again.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Lord gave them this message through Jeremiah:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what the Lord, the God of Israel, says: I made a covenant with your ancestors long ago when I rescued them from their slavery in Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I told them that every Hebrew slave must be freed after serving six years. But your ancestors paid no attention to me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Recently you repented and did what was right, following my command. You freed your slaves and made a solemn covenant with me in the Temple that bears my name.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But now you have shrugged off your oath and defiled my name by taking back the men and women you had freed, forcing them to be slaves once again.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Therefore, this is what the Lord says: Since you have not obeyed me by setting your countrymen free, I will set you free to be destroyed by war, disease, and famine. You will be an object of horror to all the nations of the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Because you have broken the terms of our covenant, I will cut you apart just as you cut apart the calf when you walked between its halves to solemnize your vows.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yes, I will cut you apart, whether you are officials of Judah or Jerusalem, court officials, priests, or common people—for you have broken your oath.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will give you to your enemies, and they will kill you. Your bodies will be food for the vultures and wild animals.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I will hand over King Zedekiah of Judah and his officials to the army of the king of Babylon. And although they have left Jerusalem for a while,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will call the Babylonian armies back again. They will fight against this city and will capture it and burn it down. I will see to it that all the towns of Judah are destroyed, with no one living there.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is the message the Lord gave Jeremiah when Jehoiakim son of Josiah was king of Judah:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Go to the settlement where the families of the Recabites live, and invite them to the Lord’s Temple. Take them into one of the inner rooms, and offer them some wine.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I went to see Jaazaniah son of Jeremiah and grandson of Habazziniah and all his brothers and sons—representing all the Recabite families.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I took them to the Temple, and we went into the room assigned to the sons of Hanan son of Igdaliah, a man of God. This room was located next to the one used by the Temple officials, directly above the room of Maaseiah son of Shallum, the Temple gatekeeper.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I set cups and jugs of wine before them and invited them to have a drink,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but they refused. “No,” they said, “we don’t drink wine, because our ancestor Jehonadab son of Recab gave us this command: ‘You and your descendants must never drink wine.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And do not build houses or plant crops or vineyards, but always live in tents. If you follow these commands, you will live long, good lives in the land.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So we have obeyed him in all these things. We have never had a drink of wine to this day, nor have our wives, our sons, or our daughters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We haven’t built houses or owned vineyards or farms or planted crops.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We have lived in tents and have fully obeyed all the commands of Jehonadab, our ancestor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon attacked this country, we were afraid of the Babylonian and Syrian armies. So we decided to move to Jerusalem. That is why we are here.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord gave this message to Jeremiah:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what the Lord of Heaven’s Armies, the God of Israel, says: Go and say to the people in Judah and Jerusalem, ‘Come and learn a lesson about how to obey me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Recabites do not drink wine to this day because their ancestor Jehonadab told them not to. But I have spoken to you again and again, and you refuse to obey me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Time after time I sent you prophets, who told you, “Turn from your wicked ways, and start doing things right. Stop worshiping other gods so that you might live in peace here in the land I have given to you and your ancestors.” But you would not listen to me or obey me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The descendants of Jehonadab son of Recab have obeyed their ancestor completely, but you have refused to listen to me.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Therefore, this is what the Lord God of Heaven’s Armies, the God of Israel, says: ‘Because you refuse to listen or answer when I call, I will send upon Judah and Jerusalem all the disasters I have threatened.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jeremiah turned to the Recabites and said, “This is what the Lord of Heaven’s Armies, the God of Israel, says: ‘You have obeyed your ancestor Jehonadab in every respect, following all his instructions.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore, this is what the Lord of Heaven’s Armies, the God of Israel, says: ‘Jehonadab son of Recab will always have descendants who serve me.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: During the fourth year that Jehoiakim son of Josiah was king in Judah, the Lord gave this message to Jeremiah:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Get a scroll, and write down all my messages against Israel, Judah, and the other nations. Begin with the first message back in the days of Josiah, and write down every message, right up to the present time.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Perhaps the people of Judah will repent when they hear again all the terrible things I have planned for them. Then I will be able to forgive their sins and wrongdoings.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jeremiah sent for Baruch son of Neriah, and as Jeremiah dictated all the prophecies that the Lord had given him, Baruch wrote them on a scroll.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jeremiah said to Baruch, “I am a prisoner here and unable to go to the Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So you go to the Temple on the next day of fasting, and read the messages from the Lord that I have had you write on this scroll. Read them so the people who are there from all over Judah will hear them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Perhaps even yet they will turn from their evil ways and ask the Lord’s forgiveness before it is too late. For the Lord has threatened them with his terrible anger.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Baruch did as Jeremiah told him and read these messages from the Lord to the people at the Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He did this on a day of sacred fasting held in late autumn, during the fifth year of the reign of Jehoiakim son of Josiah. People from all over Judah had come to Jerusalem to attend the services at the Temple on that day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Baruch read Jeremiah’s words on the scroll to all the people. He stood in front of the Temple room of Gemariah, son of Shaphan the secretary. This room was just off the upper courtyard of the Temple, near the New Gate entrance.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Micaiah son of Gemariah and grandson of Shaphan heard the messages from the Lord,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: he went down to the secretary’s room in the palace where the administrative officials were meeting. Elishama the secretary was there, along with Delaiah son of Shemaiah, Elnathan son of Acbor, Gemariah son of Shaphan, Zedekiah son of Hananiah, and all the other officials.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Micaiah told them about the messages Baruch was reading to the people,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the officials sent Jehudi son of Nethaniah, grandson of Shelemiah and great-grandson of Cushi, to ask Baruch to come and read the messages to them, too. So Baruch took the scroll and went to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Sit down and read the scroll to us,” the officials said, and Baruch did as they requested.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they heard all the messages, they looked at one another in alarm. “We must tell the king what we have heard,” they said to Baruch.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “But first, tell us how you got these messages. Did they come directly from Jeremiah?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Baruch explained, “Jeremiah dictated them, and I wrote them down in ink, word for word, on this scroll.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “You and Jeremiah should both hide,” the officials told Baruch. “Don’t tell anyone where you are!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the officials left the scroll for safekeeping in the room of Elishama the secretary and went to tell the king what had happened.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king sent Jehudi to get the scroll. Jehudi brought it from Elishama’s room and read it to the king as all his officials stood by.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It was late autumn, and the king was in a winterized part of the palace, sitting in front of a fire to keep warm.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Each time Jehudi finished reading three or four columns, the king took a knife and cut off that section of the scroll. He then threw it into the fire, section by section, until the whole scroll was burned up.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Neither the king nor his attendants showed any signs of fear or repentance at what they heard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Even when Elnathan, Delaiah, and Gemariah begged the king not to burn the scroll, he wouldn’t listen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king commanded his son Jerahmeel, Seraiah son of Azriel, and Shelemiah son of Abdeel to arrest Baruch and Jeremiah. But the Lord had hidden them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After the king had burned the scroll on which Baruch had written Jeremiah’s words, the Lord gave Jeremiah another message. He said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Get another scroll, and write everything again just as you did on the scroll King Jehoiakim burned.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then say to the king, ‘This is what the Lord says: You burned the scroll because it said the king of Babylon would destroy this land and empty it of people and animals.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now this is what the Lord says about King Jehoiakim of Judah: He will have no heirs to sit on the throne of David. His dead body will be thrown out to lie unburied—exposed to the heat of the day and the frost of the night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will punish him and his family and his attendants for their sins. I will pour out on them and on all the people of Jerusalem and Judah all the disasters I promised, for they would not listen to my warnings.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jeremiah took another scroll and dictated again to his secretary, Baruch. He wrote everything that had been on the scroll King Jehoiakim had burned in the fire. Only this time he added much more!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Zedekiah son of Josiah succeeded Jehoiachin son of Jehoiakim as the king of Judah. He was appointed by King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But neither King Zedekiah nor his attendants nor the people who were left in the land listened to what the Lord said through Jeremiah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nevertheless, King Zedekiah sent Jehucal son of Shelemiah, and Zephaniah the priest, son of Maaseiah, to ask Jeremiah, “Please pray to the Lord our God for us.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeremiah had not yet been imprisoned, so he could come and go among the people as he pleased.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At this time the army of Pharaoh Hophra of Egypt appeared at the southern border of Judah. When the Babylonian army heard about it, they withdrew from their siege of Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord gave this message to Jeremiah:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what the Lord, the God of Israel, says: The king of Judah sent you to ask me what is going to happen. Tell him, ‘Pharaoh’s army is about to return to Egypt, though he came here to help you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Babylonians will come back and capture this city and burn it to the ground.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what the Lord says: Do not fool yourselves into thinking that the Babylonians are gone for good. They aren’t!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Even if you were to destroy the entire Babylonian army, leaving only a handful of wounded survivors, they would still stagger from their tents and burn this city to the ground!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Babylonian army left Jerusalem because of Pharaoh’s approaching army,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeremiah started to leave the city on his way to the territory of Benjamin, to claim his share of the property among his relatives there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But as he was walking through the Benjamin Gate, a sentry arrested him and said, “You are defecting to the Babylonians!” The sentry making the arrest was Irijah son of Shelemiah, grandson of Hananiah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “That’s not true!” Jeremiah protested. “I had no intention of doing any such thing.” But Irijah wouldn’t listen, and he took Jeremiah before the officials.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They were furious with Jeremiah and had him flogged and imprisoned in the house of Jonathan the secretary. Jonathan’s house had been converted into a prison.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeremiah was put into a dungeon cell, where he remained for many days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Later King Zedekiah secretly requested that Jeremiah come to the palace, where the king asked him, “Do you have any messages from the Lord?”
“Yes, I do!” said Jeremiah. “You will be defeated by the king of Babylon.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jeremiah asked the king, “What crime have I committed? What have I done against you, your attendants, or the people that I should be imprisoned like this?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Where are your prophets now who told you the king of Babylon would not attack you or this land?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Listen, my lord the king, I beg you. Don’t send me back to the dungeon in the house of Jonathan the secretary, for I will die there.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So King Zedekiah commanded that Jeremiah not be returned to the dungeon. Instead, he was imprisoned in the courtyard of the guard in the royal palace. The king also commanded that Jeremiah be given a loaf of fresh bread every day as long as there was any left in the city. So Jeremiah was put in the palace prison.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Shephatiah son of Mattan, Gedaliah son of Pashhur, Jehucal son of Shelemiah, and Pashhur son of Malkijah heard what Jeremiah had been telling the people. He had been saying,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what the Lord says: ‘Everyone who stays in Jerusalem will die from war, famine, or disease, but those who surrender to the Babylonians will live. Their reward will be life. They will live!’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord also says: ‘The city of Jerusalem will certainly be handed over to the army of the king of Babylon, who will capture it.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So these officials went to the king and said, “Sir, this man must die! That kind of talk will undermine the morale of the few fighting men we have left, as well as that of all the people. This man is a traitor!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Zedekiah agreed. “All right,” he said. “Do as you like. I can’t stop you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the officials took Jeremiah from his cell and lowered him by ropes into an empty cistern in the prison yard. It belonged to Malkijah, a member of the royal family. There was no water in the cistern, but there was a thick layer of mud at the bottom, and Jeremiah sank down into it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Ebed-melech the Ethiopian, an important court official, heard that Jeremiah was in the cistern. At that time the king was holding court at the Benjamin Gate,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: so Ebed-melech rushed from the palace to speak with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “My lord the king,” he said, “these men have done a very evil thing in putting Jeremiah the prophet into the cistern. He will soon die of hunger, for almost all the bread in the city is gone.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the king told Ebed-melech, “Take thirty of my men with you, and pull Jeremiah out of the cistern before he dies.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Ebed-melech took the men with him and went to a room in the palace beneath the treasury, where he found some old rags and discarded clothing. He carried these to the cistern and lowered them to Jeremiah on a rope.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ebed-melech called down to Jeremiah, “Put these rags under your armpits to protect you from the ropes.” Then when Jeremiah was ready,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: they pulled him out. So Jeremiah was returned to the courtyard of the guard—the palace prison—where he remained.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One day King Zedekiah sent for Jeremiah and had him brought to the third entrance of the Lord’s Temple. “I want to ask you something,” the king said. “And don’t try to hide the truth.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeremiah said, “If I tell you the truth, you will kill me. And if I give you advice, you won’t listen to me anyway.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So King Zedekiah secretly promised him, “As surely as the Lord our Creator lives, I will not kill you or hand you over to the men who want you dead.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jeremiah said to Zedekiah, “This is what the Lord God of Heaven’s Armies, the God of Israel, says: ‘If you surrender to the Babylonian officers, you and your family will live, and the city will not be burned down.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if you refuse to surrender, you will not escape! This city will be handed over to the Babylonians, and they will burn it to the ground.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “But I am afraid to surrender,” the king said, “for the Babylonians may hand me over to the Judeans who have defected to them. And who knows what they will do to me!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeremiah replied, “You won’t be handed over to them if you choose to obey the Lord. Your life will be spared, and all will go well for you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if you refuse to surrender, this is what the Lord has revealed to me:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
All the women left in your palace will be brought out and given to the officers of the Babylonian army. Then the women will taunt you, saying,
‘What fine friends you have!
    They have betrayed and misled you.
When your feet sank in the mud,
    they left you to your fate!’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All your wives and children will be led out to the Babylonians, and you will not escape. You will be seized by the king of Babylon, and this city will be burned down.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Zedekiah said to Jeremiah, “Don’t tell anyone you told me this, or you will die!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: My officials may hear that I spoke to you, and they may say, ‘Tell us what you and the king were talking about. If you don’t tell us, we will kill you.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If this happens, just tell them you begged me not to send you back to Jonathan’s dungeon, for fear you would die there.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Sure enough, it wasn’t long before the king’s officials came to Jeremiah and asked him why the king had called for him. But Jeremiah followed the king’s instructions, and they left without finding out the truth. No one had overheard the conversation between Jeremiah and the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Jeremiah remained a prisoner in the courtyard of the guard until the day Jerusalem was captured.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In January of the ninth year of King Zedekiah’s reign, King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon came with his entire army to besiege Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Two and a half years later, on July 18 in the eleventh year of Zedekiah’s reign, a section of the city wall was broken down.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the officers of the Babylonian army came in and sat in triumph at the Middle Gate: Nergal-sharezer of Samgar, and Nebo-sarsekim, a chief officer, and Nergal-sharezer, the king’s adviser, and all the other officers of the king of Babylon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When King Zedekiah of Judah and all the soldiers saw that the Babylonians had broken into the city, they fled. They waited for nightfall and then slipped through the gate between the two walls behind the king’s garden and headed toward the Jordan Valley.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the Babylonian troops chased them and overtook Zedekiah on the plains of Jericho. They captured him and took him to King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon, who was at Riblah in the land of Hamath. There the king of Babylon pronounced judgment upon Zedekiah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king of Babylon made Zedekiah watch as he slaughtered his sons at Riblah. The king of Babylon also slaughtered all the nobles of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he gouged out Zedekiah’s eyes and bound him in bronze chains to lead him away to Babylon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Meanwhile, the Babylonians burned Jerusalem, including the royal palace and the houses of the people, and they tore down the walls of the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Nebuzaradan, the captain of the guard, took as exiles to Babylon the rest of the people who remained in the city, those who had defected to him, and everyone else who remained.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Nebuzaradan allowed some of the poorest people to stay behind in the land of Judah, and he assigned them to care for the vineyards and fields.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Nebuchadnezzar had told Nebuzaradan, the captain of the guard, to find Jeremiah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “See that he isn’t hurt,” he said. “Look after him well, and give him anything he wants.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Nebuzaradan, the captain of the guard; Nebushazban, a chief officer; Nergal-sharezer, the king’s adviser; and the other officers of Babylon’s king
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: sent messengers to bring Jeremiah out of the prison. They put him under the care of Gedaliah son of Ahikam and grandson of Shaphan, who took him back to his home. So Jeremiah stayed in Judah among his own people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord had given the following message to Jeremiah while he was still in prison:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Say to Ebed-melech the Ethiopian, ‘This is what the Lord of Heaven’s Armies, the God of Israel, says: I will do to this city everything I have threatened. I will send disaster, not prosperity. You will see its destruction,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but I will rescue you from those you fear so much.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Because you trusted me, I will give you your life as a reward. I will rescue you and keep you safe. I, the Lord, have spoken!’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord gave a message to Jeremiah after Nebuzaradan, the captain of the guard, had released him at Ramah. He had found Jeremiah bound in chains among all the other captives of Jerusalem and Judah who were being sent to exile in Babylon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The captain of the guard called for Jeremiah and said, “The Lord your God has brought this disaster on this land,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: just as he said he would. For these people have sinned against the Lord and disobeyed him. That is why it happened.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But I am going to take off your chains and let you go. If you want to come with me to Babylon, you are welcome. I will see that you are well cared for. But if you don’t want to come, you may stay here. The whole land is before you—go wherever you like.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If you decide to stay, then return to Gedaliah son of Ahikam and grandson of Shaphan. He has been appointed governor of Judah by the king of Babylon. Stay there with the people he rules. But it’s up to you; go wherever you like.”
Then Nebuzaradan, the captain of the guard, gave Jeremiah some food and money and let him go.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jeremiah returned to Gedaliah son of Ahikam at Mizpah, and he lived in Judah with the few who were still left in the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The leaders of the Judean military groups in the countryside heard that the king of Babylon had appointed Gedaliah son of Ahikam as governor over the poor people who were left behind in Judah—the men, women, and children who hadn’t been exiled to Babylon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they went to see Gedaliah at Mizpah. These included: Ishmael son of Nethaniah, Johanan and Jonathan sons of Kareah, Seraiah son of Tanhumeth, the sons of Ephai the Netophathite, Jezaniah son of the Maacathite, and all their men.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Gedaliah vowed to them that the Babylonians meant them no harm. “Don’t be afraid to serve them. Live in the land and serve the king of Babylon, and all will go well for you,” he promised.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “As for me, I will stay at Mizpah to represent you before the Babylonians who come to meet with us. Settle in the towns you have taken, and live off the land. Harvest the grapes and summer fruits and olives, and store them away.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Judeans in Moab, Ammon, Edom, and the other nearby countries heard that the king of Babylon had left a few people in Judah and that Gedaliah was the governor,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: they began to return to Judah from the places to which they had fled. They stopped at Mizpah to meet with Gedaliah and then went into the Judean countryside to gather a great harvest of grapes and other crops.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Soon after this, Johanan son of Kareah and the other military leaders came to Gedaliah at Mizpah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They said to him, “Did you know that Baalis, king of Ammon, has sent Ishmael son of Nethaniah to assassinate you?” But Gedaliah refused to believe them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Later Johanan had a private conference with Gedaliah and volunteered to kill Ishmael secretly. “Why should we let him come and murder you?” Johanan asked. “What will happen then to the Judeans who have returned? Why should the few of us who are still left be scattered and lost?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Gedaliah said to Johanan, “I forbid you to do any such thing, for you are lying about Ishmael.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But in midautumn of that year, Ishmael son of Nethaniah and grandson of Elishama, who was a member of the royal family and had been one of the king’s high officials, went to Mizpah with ten men to meet Gedaliah. While they were eating together,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ishmael and his ten men suddenly jumped up, drew their swords, and killed Gedaliah, whom the king of Babylon had appointed governor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ishmael also killed all the Judeans and the Babylonian soldiers who were with Gedaliah at Mizpah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The next day, before anyone had heard about Gedaliah’s murder,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: eighty men arrived from Shechem, Shiloh, and Samaria to worship at the Temple of the Lord. They had shaved off their beards, torn their clothes, and cut themselves, and had brought along grain offerings and frankincense.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ishmael left Mizpah to meet them, weeping as he went. When he reached them, he said, “Oh, come and see what has happened to Gedaliah!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But as soon as they were all inside the town, Ishmael and his men killed all but ten of them and threw their bodies into a cistern.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The other ten had talked Ishmael into letting them go by promising to bring him their stores of wheat, barley, olive oil, and honey that they had hidden away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The cistern where Ishmael dumped the bodies of the men he murdered was the large one dug by King Asa when he fortified Mizpah to protect himself against King Baasha of Israel. Ishmael son of Nethaniah filled it with corpses.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Ishmael made captives of the king’s daughters and the other people who had been left under Gedaliah’s care in Mizpah by Nebuzaradan, the captain of the guard. Taking them with him, he started back toward the land of Ammon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when Johanan son of Kareah and the other military leaders heard about Ishmael’s crimes,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: they took all their men and set out to stop him. They caught up with him at the large pool near Gibeon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people Ishmael had captured shouted for joy when they saw Johanan and the other military leaders.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And all the captives from Mizpah escaped and began to help Johanan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Meanwhile, Ishmael and eight of his men escaped from Johanan into the land of Ammon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Johanan son of Kareah and the other military leaders took all the people they had rescued in Gibeon—the soldiers, women, children, and court officials whom Ishmael had captured after he killed Gedaliah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They took them all to the village of Geruth-kimham near Bethlehem, where they prepared to leave for Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They were afraid of what the Babylonians would do when they heard that Ishmael had killed Gedaliah, the governor appointed by the Babylonian king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then all the military leaders, including Johanan son of Kareah and Jezaniah son of Hoshaiah, and all the people, from the least to the greatest, approached
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeremiah the prophet. They said, “Please pray to the Lord your God for us. As you can see, we are only a tiny remnant compared to what we were before.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pray that the Lord your God will show us what to do and where to go.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “All right,” Jeremiah replied. “I will pray to the Lord your God, as you have asked, and I will tell you everything he says. I will hide nothing from you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they said to Jeremiah, “May the Lord your God be a faithful witness against us if we refuse to obey whatever he tells us to do!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whether we like it or not, we will obey the Lord our God to whom we are sending you with our plea. For if we obey him, everything will turn out well for us.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ten days later the Lord gave his reply to Jeremiah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he called for Johanan son of Kareah and the other military leaders, and for all the people, from the least to the greatest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said to them, “You sent me to the Lord, the God of Israel, with your request, and this is his reply:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Stay here in this land. If you do, I will build you up and not tear you down; I will plant you and not uproot you. For I am sorry about all the punishment I have had to bring upon you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Do not fear the king of Babylon anymore,’ says the Lord. ‘For I am with you and will save you and rescue you from his power.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will be merciful to you by making him kind, so he will let you stay here in your land.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “But if you refuse to obey the Lord your God, and if you say, ‘We will not stay here;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: instead, we will go to Egypt where we will be free from war, the call to arms, and hunger,’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then hear the Lord’s message to the remnant of Judah. This is what the Lord of Heaven’s Armies, the God of Israel, says: ‘If you are determined to go to Egypt and live there,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the very war and famine you fear will catch up to you, and you will die there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That is the fate awaiting every one of you who insists on going to live in Egypt. Yes, you will die from war, famine, and disease. None of you will escape the disaster I will bring upon you there.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what the Lord of Heaven’s Armies, the God of Israel, says: ‘Just as my anger and fury have been poured out on the people of Jerusalem, so they will be poured out on you when you enter Egypt. You will be an object of damnation, horror, cursing, and mockery. And you will never see your homeland again.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Listen, you remnant of Judah. The Lord has told you: ‘Do not go to Egypt!’ Don’t forget this warning I have given you today.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For you were not being honest when you sent me to pray to the Lord your God for you. You said, ‘Just tell us what the Lord our God says, and we will do it!’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And today I have told you exactly what he said, but you will not obey the Lord your God any better now than you have in the past.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So you can be sure that you will die from war, famine, and disease in Egypt, where you insist on going.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Jeremiah had finished giving this message from the Lord their God to all the people,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Azariah son of Hoshaiah and Johanan son of Kareah and all the other proud men said to Jeremiah, “You lie! The Lord our God hasn’t forbidden us to go to Egypt!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Baruch son of Neriah has convinced you to say this, because he wants us to stay here and be killed by the Babylonians or be carried off into exile.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Johanan and the other military leaders and all the people refused to obey the Lord’s command to stay in Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Johanan and the other leaders took with them all the people who had returned from the nearby countries to which they had fled.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the crowd were men, women, and children, the king’s daughters, and all those whom Nebuzaradan, the captain of the guard, had left with Gedaliah. The prophet Jeremiah and Baruch were also included.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people refused to obey the voice of the Lord and went to Egypt, going as far as the city of Tahpanhes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then at Tahpanhes, the Lord gave another message to Jeremiah. He said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “While the people of Judah are watching, take some large rocks and bury them under the pavement stones at the entrance of Pharaoh’s palace here in Tahpanhes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then say to the people of Judah, ‘This is what the Lord of Heaven’s Armies, the God of Israel, says: I will certainly bring my servant Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, here to Egypt. I will set his throne over these stones that I have hidden. He will spread his royal canopy over them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And when he comes, he will destroy the land of Egypt. He will bring death to those destined for death, captivity to those destined for captivity, and war to those destined for war.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He will set fire to the temples of Egypt’s gods; he will burn the temples and carry the idols away as plunder. He will pick clean the land of Egypt as a shepherd picks fleas from his cloak. And he himself will leave unharmed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He will break down the sacred pillars standing in the temple of the sun in Egypt, and he will burn down the temples of Egypt’s gods.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is the message Jeremiah received concerning the Judeans living in northern Egypt in the cities of Migdol, Tahpanhes, and Memphis, and in southern Egypt as well:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what the Lord of Heaven’s Armies, the God of Israel, says: You saw the calamity I brought on Jerusalem and all the towns of Judah. They now lie deserted and in ruins.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They provoked my anger with all their wickedness. They burned incense and worshiped other gods—gods that neither they nor you nor any of your ancestors had ever even known.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Again and again I sent my servants, the prophets, to plead with them, ‘Don’t do these horrible things that I hate so much.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But my people would not listen or turn back from their wicked ways. They kept on burning incense to these gods.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And so my fury boiled over and fell like fire on the towns of Judah and into the streets of Jerusalem, and they are still a desolate ruin today.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “And now the Lord God of Heaven’s Armies, the God of Israel, asks you: Why are you destroying yourselves? For not one of you will survive—not a man, woman, or child among you who has come here from Judah, not even the babies in your arms.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Why provoke my anger by burning incense to the idols you have made here in Egypt? You will only destroy yourselves and make yourselves an object of cursing and mockery for all the nations of the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Have you forgotten the sins of your ancestors, the sins of the kings and queens of Judah, and the sins you and your wives committed in Judah and Jerusalem?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: To this very hour you have shown no remorse or reverence. No one has chosen to follow my word and the decrees I gave to you and your ancestors before you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Therefore, this is what the Lord of Heaven’s Armies, the God of Israel, says: I am determined to destroy every one of you!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will take this remnant of Judah—those who were determined to come here and live in Egypt—and I will consume them. They will fall here in Egypt, killed by war and famine. All will die, from the least to the greatest. They will be an object of damnation, horror, cursing, and mockery.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will punish them in Egypt just as I punished them in Jerusalem, by war, famine, and disease.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Of that remnant who fled to Egypt, hoping someday to return to Judah, there will be no survivors. Even though they long to return home, only a handful will do so.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then all the women present and all the men who knew that their wives had burned incense to idols—a great crowd of all the Judeans living in northern Egypt and southern Egypt—answered Jeremiah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “We will not listen to your messages from the Lord!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We will do whatever we want. We will burn incense and pour out liquid offerings to the Queen of Heaven just as much as we like—just as we, and our ancestors, and our kings and officials have always done in the towns of Judah and in the streets of Jerusalem. For in those days we had plenty to eat, and we were well off and had no troubles!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But ever since we quit burning incense to the Queen of Heaven and stopped worshiping her with liquid offerings, we have been in great trouble and have been dying from war and famine.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Besides,” the women added, “do you suppose that we were burning incense and pouring out liquid offerings to the Queen of Heaven, and making cakes marked with her image, without our husbands knowing it and helping us? Of course not!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jeremiah said to all of them, men and women alike, who had given him that answer,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Do you think the Lord did not know that you and your ancestors, your kings and officials, and all the people were burning incense to idols in the towns of Judah and in the streets of Jerusalem?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It was because the Lord could no longer bear all the disgusting things you were doing that he made your land an object of cursing—a desolate ruin without inhabitants—as it is today.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All these terrible things happened to you because you have burned incense to idols and sinned against the Lord. You have refused to obey him and have not followed his instructions, his decrees, and his laws.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jeremiah said to them all, including the women, “Listen to this message from the Lord, all you citizens of Judah who live in Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what the Lord of Heaven’s Armies, the God of Israel, says: ‘You and your wives have said, “We will keep our promises to burn incense and pour out liquid offerings to the Queen of Heaven,” and you have proved by your actions that you meant it. So go ahead and carry out your promises and vows to her!’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “But listen to this message from the Lord, all you Judeans now living in Egypt: ‘I have sworn by my great name,’ says the Lord, ‘that my name will no longer be spoken by any of the Judeans in the land of Egypt. None of you may invoke my name or use this oath: “As surely as the Sovereign Lord lives.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For I will watch over you to bring you disaster and not good. Everyone from Judah who is now living in Egypt will suffer war and famine until all of you are dead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Only a small number will escape death and return to Judah from Egypt. Then all those who came to Egypt will find out whose words are true—mine or theirs!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “‘And this is the proof I give you,’ says the Lord, ‘that all I have threatened will happen to you and that I will punish you here.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what the Lord says: ‘I will turn Pharaoh Hophra, king of Egypt, over to his enemies who want to kill him, just as I turned King Zedekiah of Judah over to King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The prophet Jeremiah gave a message to Baruch son of Neriah in the fourth year of the reign of Jehoiakim son of Josiah, after Baruch had written down everything Jeremiah had dictated to him. He said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what the Lord, the God of Israel, says to you, Baruch:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You have said, ‘I am overwhelmed with trouble! Haven’t I had enough pain already? And now the Lord has added more! I am worn out from sighing and can find no rest.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Baruch, this is what the Lord says: ‘I will destroy this nation that I built. I will uproot what I planted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Are you seeking great things for yourself? Don’t do it! I will bring great disaster upon all these people; but I will give you your life as a reward wherever you go. I, the Lord, have spoken!’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The following messages were given to Jeremiah the prophet from the Lord concerning foreign nations.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This message concerning Egypt was given in the fourth year of the reign of Jehoiakim son of Josiah, the king of Judah, on the occasion of the battle of Carchemish when Pharaoh Neco, king of Egypt, and his army were defeated beside the Euphrates River by King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Prepare your shields,
    and advance into battle!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Harness the horses,
    and mount the stallions.
Take your positions.
    Put on your helmets.
Sharpen your spears,
    and prepare your armor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But what do I see?
    The Egyptian army flees in terror.
The bravest of its fighting men run
    without a backward glance.
They are terrorized at every turn,”
    says the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“The swiftest runners cannot flee;
    the mightiest warriors cannot escape.
By the Euphrates River to the north,
    they stumble and fall.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Who is this, rising like the Nile at floodtime,
    overflowing all the land?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It is the Egyptian army,
    overflowing all the land,
boasting that it will cover the earth like a flood,
    destroying cities and their people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Charge, you horses and chariots;
    attack, you mighty warriors of Egypt!
Come, all you allies from Ethiopia, Libya, and Lydia
    who are skilled with the shield and bow!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For this is the day of the Lord, the Lord of Heaven’s Armies,
    a day of vengeance on his enemies.
The sword will devour until it is satisfied,
    yes, until it is drunk with your blood!
The Lord, the Lord of Heaven’s Armies, will receive a sacrifice today
    in the north country beside the Euphrates River.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Go up to Gilead to get medicine,
    O virgin daughter of Egypt!
But your many treatments
    will bring you no healing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The nations have heard of your shame.
    The earth is filled with your cries of despair.
Your mightiest warriors will run into each other
    and fall down together.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord gave the prophet Jeremiah this message about King Nebuchadnezzar’s plans to attack Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Shout it out in Egypt!
    Publish it in the cities of Migdol, Memphis, and Tahpanhes!
Mobilize for battle,
    for the sword will devour everyone around you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Why have your warriors fallen?
    They cannot stand, for the Lord has knocked them down.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They stumble and fall over each other
    and say among themselves,
‘Come, let’s go back to our people,
    to the land of our birth.
    Let’s get away from the sword of the enemy!’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
There they will say,
    ‘Pharaoh, the king of Egypt, is a loudmouth
    who missed his opportunity!’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“As surely as I live,” says the King,
    whose name is the Lord of Heaven’s Armies,
“one is coming against Egypt
    who is as tall as Mount Tabor,
    or as Mount Carmel by the sea!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Pack up! Get ready to leave for exile,
    you citizens of Egypt!
The city of Memphis will be destroyed,
    without a single inhabitant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Egypt is as sleek as a beautiful heifer,
    but a horsefly from the north is on its way!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Egypt’s mercenaries have become like fattened calves.
    They, too, will turn and run,
for it is a day of great disaster for Egypt,
    a time of great punishment.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
They will cut down her people like trees,” says the Lord,
    “for they are more numerous than locusts.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Egypt will be humiliated;
    she will be handed over to people from the north.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord of Heaven’s Armies, the God of Israel, says: “I will punish Amon, the god of Thebes, and all the other gods of Egypt. I will punish its rulers and Pharaoh, too, and all who trust in him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will hand them over to those who want them killed—to King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon and his army. But afterward the land will recover from the ravages of war. I, the Lord, have spoken!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“But do not be afraid, Jacob, my servant;
    do not be dismayed, Israel.
For I will bring you home again from distant lands,
    and your children will return from their exile.
Israel will return to a life of peace and quiet,
    and no one will terrorize them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not be afraid, Jacob, my servant,
    for I am with you,” says the Lord.
“I will completely destroy the nations to which I have exiled you,
    but I will not completely destroy you.
I will discipline you, but with justice;
    I cannot let you go unpunished.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is the Lord’s message to the prophet Jeremiah concerning the Philistines of Gaza, before it was captured by the Egyptian army.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is what the Lord says:
“A flood is coming from the north
    to overflow the land.
It will destroy the land and everything in it—
    cities and people alike.
People will scream in terror,
    and everyone in the land will wail.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Hear the clatter of stallions’ hooves
    and the rumble of wheels as the chariots rush by.
Terrified fathers run madly,
    without a backward glance at their helpless children.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“The time has come for the Philistines to be destroyed,
    along with their allies from Tyre and Sidon.
Yes, the Lord is destroying the remnant of the Philistines,
    those colonists from the island of Crete.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Gaza will be humiliated, its head shaved bald;
    Ashkelon will lie silent.
You remnant from the Mediterranean coast,
    how long will you cut yourselves in mourning?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Now, O sword of the Lord,
    when will you be at rest again?
Go back into your sheath;
    rest and be still.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“But how can it be still
    when the Lord has sent it on a mission?
For the city of Ashkelon
    and the people living along the sea
    must be destroyed.”
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
No one will ever brag about Moab again,
    for in Heshbon there is a plot to destroy her.
‘Come,’ they say, ‘we will cut her off from being a nation.’
    The town of Madmen, too, will be silenced;
    the sword will follow you there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Listen to the cries from Horonaim,
    cries of devastation and great destruction.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
All Moab is destroyed.
    Her little ones will cry out.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Her refugees weep bitterly,
    climbing the slope to Luhith.
They cry out in terror,
    descending the slope to Horonaim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Flee for your lives!
    Hide in the wilderness!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Because you have trusted in your wealth and skill,
    you will be taken captive.
Your god Chemosh, with his priests and officials,
    will be hauled off to distant lands!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“All the towns will be destroyed,
    and no one will escape—
either on the plateaus or in the valleys,
    for the Lord has spoken.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Oh, that Moab had wings
    so she could fly away,
for her towns will be left empty,
    with no one living in them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Cursed are those who refuse to do the Lord’s work,
    who hold back their swords from shedding blood!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“From his earliest history, Moab has lived in peace,
    never going into exile.
He is like wine that has been allowed to settle.
    He has not been poured from flask to flask,
    and he is now fragrant and smooth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But the time is coming soon,” says the Lord,
    “when I will send men to pour him from his jar.
They will pour him out,
    then shatter the jar!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
At last Moab will be ashamed of his idol Chemosh,
    as the people of Israel were ashamed of their gold calf at Bethel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“You used to boast, ‘We are heroes,
    mighty men of war.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But now Moab and his towns will be destroyed.
    His most promising youth are doomed to slaughter,”
    says the King, whose name is the Lord of Heaven’s Armies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Destruction is coming fast for Moab;
    calamity threatens ominously.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You friends of Moab,
    weep for him and cry!
See how the strong scepter is broken,
    how the beautiful staff is shattered!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Come down from your glory
    and sit in the dust, you people of Dibon,
for those who destroy Moab will shatter Dibon, too.
    They will tear down all your towers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You people of Aroer,
    stand beside the road and watch.
Shout to those who flee from Moab,
    ‘What has happened there?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“And the reply comes back,
‘Moab lies in ruins, disgraced;
    weep and wail!
Tell it by the banks of the Arnon River:
    Moab has been destroyed!’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Judgment has been poured out on the towns of the plateau—
    on Holon and Jahaz and Mephaath,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: on Dibon and Nebo and Beth-diblathaim,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: on Kiriathaim and Beth-gamul and Beth-meon,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
on Kerioth and Bozrah—
    all the towns of Moab, far and near.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“The strength of Moab has ended.
    His arm has been broken,” says the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Let him stagger and fall like a drunkard,
    for he has rebelled against the Lord.
Moab will wallow in his own vomit,
    ridiculed by all.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Did you not ridicule the people of Israel?
    Were they caught in the company of thieves
    that you should despise them as you do?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“You people of Moab,
    flee from your towns and live in the caves.
Hide like doves that nest
    in the clefts of the rocks.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
We have all heard of the pride of Moab,
    for his pride is very great.
We know of his lofty pride,
    his arrogance, and his haughty heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I know about his insolence,”
    says the Lord,
“but his boasts are empty—
    as empty as his deeds.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
“You people of Sibmah, rich in vineyards,
    I will weep for you even more than I did for Jazer.
Your spreading vines once reached as far as the Dead Sea,
    but the destroyer has stripped you bare!
    He has harvested your grapes and summer fruits.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Joy and gladness are gone from fruitful Moab.
    The presses yield no wine.
No one treads the grapes with shouts of joy.
    There is shouting, yes, but not of joy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Instead, their awful cries of terror can be heard from Heshbon clear across to Elealeh and Jahaz; from Zoar all the way to Horonaim and Eglath-shelishiyah. Even the waters of Nimrim are dried up now.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I will put an end to Moab,” says the Lord, “for the people offer sacrifices at the pagan shrines and burn incense to their false gods.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: My heart moans like a flute for Moab and Kir-hareseth, for all their wealth has disappeared.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people shave their heads and beards in mourning. They slash their hands and put on clothes made of burlap.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There is crying and sorrow in every Moabite home and on every street. For I have smashed Moab like an old, unwanted jar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: How it is shattered! Hear the wailing! See the shame of Moab! It has become an object of ridicule, an example of ruin to all its neighbors.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is what the Lord says:
“Look! The enemy swoops down like an eagle,
    spreading his wings over Moab.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Its cities will fall,
    and its strongholds will be seized.
Even the mightiest warriors will be in anguish
    like a woman in labor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Moab will no longer be a nation,
    for it has boasted against the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Terror and traps and snares will be your lot,
    O Moab,” says the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Those who flee in terror will fall into a trap,
    and those who escape the trap will step into a snare.
I will see to it that you do not get away,
    for the time of your judgment has come,”
    says the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“The people flee as far as Heshbon
    but are unable to go on.
For a fire comes from Heshbon,
    King Sihon’s ancient home,
to devour the entire land
    with all its rebellious people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“What sorrow awaits you, O people of Moab!
    The people of the god Chemosh are destroyed!
Your sons and your daughters
    have been taken away as captives.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But I will restore the fortunes of Moab
    in days to come.
    I, the Lord, have spoken!”
This is the end of Jeremiah’s prophecy concerning Moab.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This message was given concerning the Ammonites. This is what the Lord says:
“Are there no descendants of Israel
    to inherit the land of Gad?
Why are you, who worship Molech,
    living in its towns?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
In the days to come,” says the Lord,
    “I will sound the battle cry against your city of Rabbah.
It will become a desolate heap of ruins,
    and the neighboring towns will be burned.
Then Israel will take back the land
    you took from her,” says the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Cry out, O Heshbon,
    for the town of Ai is destroyed.
Weep, O people of Rabbah!
    Put on your clothes of mourning.
Weep and wail, hiding in the hedges,
    for your god Molech, with his priests and officials,
    will be hauled off to distant lands.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You are proud of your fertile valleys,
    but they will soon be ruined.
You trusted in your wealth,
    you rebellious daughter,
    and thought no one could ever harm you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But look! I will bring terror upon you,”
    says the Lord, the Lord of Heaven’s Armies.
“Your neighbors will chase you from your land,
    and no one will help your exiles as they flee.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But I will restore the fortunes of the Ammonites
    in days to come.
    I, the Lord, have spoken.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This message was given concerning Edom. This is what the Lord of Heaven’s Armies says:
“Is there no wisdom in Teman?
    Is no one left to give wise counsel?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Turn and flee!
    Hide in deep caves, you people of Dedan!
For when I bring disaster on Edom,
    I will punish you, too!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Those who harvest grapes
    always leave a few for the poor.
If thieves came at night,
    they would not take everything.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But I will strip bare the land of Edom,
    and there will be no place left to hide.
Its children, its brothers, and its neighbors
    will all be destroyed,
    and Edom itself will be no more.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But I will protect the orphans who remain among you.
    Your widows, too, can depend on me for help.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And this is what the Lord says: “If the innocent must suffer, how much more must you! You will not go unpunished! You must drink this cup of judgment!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For I have sworn by my own name,” says the Lord, “that Bozrah will become an object of horror and a heap of ruins; it will be mocked and cursed. All its towns and villages will be desolate forever.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I have heard a message from the Lord
    that an ambassador was sent to the nations to say,
“Form a coalition against Edom,
    and prepare for battle!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Lord says to Edom,
“I will cut you down to size among the nations.
    You will be despised by all.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You have been deceived
    by the fear you inspire in others
    and by your own pride.
You live in a rock fortress
    and control the mountain heights.
But even if you make your nest among the peaks with the eagles,
    I will bring you crashing down,”
    says the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Edom will be an object of horror.
    All who pass by will be appalled
    and will gasp at the destruction they see there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It will be like the destruction of Sodom and Gomorrah
    and their neighboring towns,” says the Lord.
“No one will live there;
    no one will inhabit it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will come like a lion from the thickets of the Jordan,
    leaping on the sheep in the pasture.
I will chase Edom from its land,
    and I will appoint the leader of my choice.
For who is like me, and who can challenge me?
    What ruler can oppose my will?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Listen to the Lord’s plans against Edom
    and the people of Teman.
Even the little children will be dragged off like sheep,
    and their homes will be destroyed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The earth will shake with the noise of Edom’s fall,
    and its cry of despair will be heard all the way to the Red Sea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Look! The enemy swoops down like an eagle,
    spreading his wings over Bozrah.
Even the mightiest warriors will be in anguish
    like a woman in labor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This message was given concerning Damascus. This is what the Lord says:
“The towns of Hamath and Arpad are struck with fear,
    for they have heard the news of their destruction.
Their hearts are troubled
    like a wild sea in a raging storm.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Damascus has become feeble,
    and all her people turn to flee.
Fear, anguish, and pain have gripped her
    as they grip a woman in labor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
That famous city, a city of joy,
    will be forsaken!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Her young men will fall in the streets and die.
    Her soldiers will all be killed,”
    says the Lord of Heaven’s Armies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“And I will set fire to the walls of Damascus
    that will burn up the palaces of Ben-hadad.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This message was given concerning Kedar and the kingdoms of Hazor, which were attacked by King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon. This is what the Lord says:
“Advance against Kedar!
    Destroy the warriors from the East!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Their flocks and tents will be captured,
    and their household goods and camels will be taken away.
Everywhere shouts of panic will be heard:
    ‘We are terrorized at every turn!’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Run for your lives,” says the Lord.
    “Hide yourselves in deep caves, you people of Hazor,
for King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon has plotted against you
    and is preparing to destroy you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Go up and attack that complacent nation,”
    says the Lord.
“Its people live alone in the desert
    without walls or gates.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Their camels and other livestock will all be yours.
    I will scatter to the winds these people
    who live in remote places.
I will bring calamity upon them
    from every direction,” says the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Hazor will be inhabited by jackals,
    and it will be desolate forever.
No one will live there;
    no one will inhabit it.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This message concerning Elam came to the prophet Jeremiah from the Lord at the beginning of the reign of King Zedekiah of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is what the Lord of Heaven’s Armies says:
“I will destroy the archers of Elam—
    the best of their forces.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will bring enemies from all directions,
    and I will scatter the people of Elam to the four winds.
    They will be exiled to countries around the world.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I myself will go with Elam’s enemies to shatter it.
    In my fierce anger, I will bring great disaster
    upon the people of Elam,” says the Lord.
“Their enemies will chase them with the sword
    until I have destroyed them completely.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will set my throne in Elam,” says the Lord,
    “and I will destroy its king and officials.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But I will restore the fortunes of Elam
    in days to come.
    I, the Lord, have spoken!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord gave Jeremiah the prophet this message concerning Babylon and the land of the Babylonians.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is what the Lord says:
“Tell the whole world,
    and keep nothing back.
Raise a signal flag
    to tell everyone that Babylon will fall!
Her images and idols will be shattered.
    Her gods Bel and Marduk will be utterly disgraced.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For a nation will attack her from the north
    and bring such destruction that no one will live there again.
Everything will be gone;
    both people and animals will flee.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“In those coming days,”
    says the Lord,
“the people of Israel will return home
    together with the people of Judah.
They will come weeping
    and seeking the Lord their God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They will ask the way to Jerusalem
    and will start back home again.
They will bind themselves to the Lord
    with an eternal covenant that will never be forgotten.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“My people have been lost sheep.
    Their shepherds have led them astray
    and turned them loose in the mountains.
They have lost their way
    and can’t remember how to get back to the sheepfold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
All who found them devoured them.
    Their enemies said,
‘We did nothing wrong in attacking them,
    for they sinned against the Lord,
their true place of rest,
    and the hope of their ancestors.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“But now, flee from Babylon!
    Leave the land of the Babylonians.
Like male goats at the head of the flock,
    lead my people home again.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For I am raising up an army
    of great nations from the north.
They will join forces to attack Babylon,
    and she will be captured.
The enemies’ arrows will go straight to the mark;
    they will not miss!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Babylonia will be looted
    until the attackers are glutted with loot.
    I, the Lord, have spoken!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“You rejoice and are glad,
    you who plundered my chosen people.
You frisk about like a calf in a meadow
    and neigh like a stallion.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But your homeland will be overwhelmed
    with shame and disgrace.
You will become the least of nations—
    a wilderness, a dry and desolate land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Because of the Lord’s anger,
    Babylon will become a deserted wasteland.
All who pass by will be horrified
    and will gasp at the destruction they see there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Yes, prepare to attack Babylon,
    all you surrounding nations.
Let your archers shoot at her; spare no arrows.
    For she has sinned against the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Shout war cries against her from every side.
    Look! She surrenders!
    Her walls have fallen.
It is the Lord’s vengeance,
    so take vengeance on her.
    Do to her as she has done to others!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Take from Babylon all those who plant crops;
    send all the harvesters away.
Because of the sword of the enemy,
    everyone will run away and rush back to their own lands.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“The Israelites are like sheep
    that have been scattered by lions.
First the king of Assyria ate them up.
    Then King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon cracked their bones.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Therefore, this is what the Lord of Heaven’s Armies,
    the God of Israel, says:
“Now I will punish the king of Babylon and his land,
    just as I punished the king of Assyria.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
And I will bring Israel home again to its own land,
    to feed in the fields of Carmel and Bashan,
and to be satisfied once more
    in the hill country of Ephraim and Gilead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
In those days,” says the Lord,
    “no sin will be found in Israel or in Judah,
    for I will forgive the remnant I preserve.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Go up, my warriors, against the land of Merathaim
    and against the people of Pekod.
Pursue, kill, and completely destroy them,
    as I have commanded you,” says the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Let the battle cry be heard in the land,
    a shout of great destruction.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Babylon, the mightiest hammer in all the earth,
    lies broken and shattered.
    Babylon is desolate among the nations!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Listen, Babylon, for I have set a trap for you.
    You are caught, for you have fought against the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Lord has opened his armory
    and brought out weapons to vent his fury.
The terror that falls upon the Babylonians
    will be the work of the Sovereign Lord of Heaven’s Armies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yes, come against her from distant lands.
    Break open her granaries.
Crush her walls and houses into heaps of rubble.
    Destroy her completely, and leave nothing!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Destroy even her young bulls—
    it will be terrible for them, too!
Slaughter them all!
